content: How can I help you today?

Well, my wife encouraged me to come talk to someone. Things at home are really tough right now. My son has been acting out a lot, and it’s affecting my relationship with my wife. I honestly don’t even know where to start with all this.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like a lot has been going on for you—things with your son, and how it’s impacting your relationship with your wife. That can be really overwhelming, and it’s understandable to feel unsure about where to begin. What feels most important for you to talk about right now?

I guess the situation with my son feels like the heart of everything. He's been struggling with his behavior; acting out, getting into trouble at school, and it's been exhausting trying to figure out what to do. My wife and I can't seem to agree on the best way to handle it, which just adds more stress at home.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot right now—trying to support your son while also navigating differences with your wife about how to approach the situation. That must feel draining and frustrating. How have you been managing all of this so far?

Honestly, I don't think I've been managing it well. I've just been trying to get through each day, but it feels like I'm constantly stuck in this cycle of stress and frustration. I shut down a lot, and I think that's making things worse between me and my wife. I just don’t know what else to do.

It seems like you’re feeling stuck and depleted, and shutting down has been your way of trying to cope with the stress. It’s understandable that, with all this going on, it’s been hard to find the energy or clarity to respond differently. What do you think might help lighten the load or break out of this cycle, even just a little bit?

I honestly don't know what would help right now. Everything feels so overwhelming that it's hard to see a way out or even know where to start. I just wish I could figure out how to help my son, and maybe that would ease some of the tension at home. But I feel lost.

It seems like your priority right now is really focusing on helping your son, but feeling lost about how to do that has made it overwhelming. You care deeply about your family, and that’s clear in what you’re sharing. What do you think your son might need most from you right now?

I wish I knew the answer to that. He’s been so angry and difficult to reach lately, and I can’t tell if he’s dealing with something deeper or just acting out for attention. I feel like I’ve tried being patient, setting boundaries, and talking to him, but nothing seems to work. It’s like I’ve run out of ideas, and I’m failing him.

It sounds like you’ve been putting a lot of effort into trying different approaches with your son, and even though it feels like nothing is working, it shows how much you care about him and how committed you are as a parent. Feeling like you’re failing must be really heavy to carry, especially when you’re doing so much already. What would it mean for you to gain more clarity about what might be going on for him?

I guess it would mean everything. If I could just understand what's really going on with him, maybe I’d have a better idea of how to help. Right now, it all feels like guesswork, and that’s frustrating. I don’t even know where to start looking for answers though.

It sounds like understanding your son’s struggles feels like a key piece for you—a way to move forward with less guesswork and more focus. It’s frustrating to feel like you’re searching for answers without direction. What do you think could be a first small step toward understanding what’s behind his behavior?

I don’t know, maybe talking to his teachers or seeing if there’s a counselor at his school who could give some insight? It’s hard to tell, but maybe they can see things I’m missing. Or... maybe he needs someone else to talk to, like a professional, because I clearly haven’t been able to get through to him.

Reaching out to his teachers or a school counselor could be a really helpful step—they might have a different perspective or see patterns that could provide some insight. It also sounds like you’re considering the possibility of involving a professional to support him and create space for him to open up in a way he might not feel able to at home. What do you think about exploring these ideas further?

Yeah, I think it’s worth looking into. I mean, I’ve been avoiding going down that road because it makes me feel like I’ve failed as a parent, but at this point, if it helps him, I’ll do it. I guess I could start by talking to his school and seeing what they recommend.

You're showing a lot of strength in being open to these steps, even though it’s hard and may feel like you’ve stumbled. Wanting to support your son however you can really shows your dedication to him. Starting with the school sounds like a thoughtful approach—they can often offer perspective and even resources or suggestions. How does it feel to think about taking this as your first step?

It feels a bit overwhelming, if I’m being honest, but also like it might be the right thing to do. If it could help my son, then it’s worth a try. I’ll see what his teachers or the school counselor have to say and go from there.

That’s a big step, and it’s clear how much you’re prioritizing your son’s well-being, even when it feels overwhelming. Taking this step could open the door to understanding more about what’s going on for him. Is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to talk about before you move forward?
No, I think that’s all for now. Thank you for listening and helping me sort through this. I’m going to start with the school and see where that leads. I appreciate your time today.
